title: bowl
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: (Christie's London) sold on June 25, 1984 to Harrison Eiteljorg [1903-1997] of Indianapolis; donated to the IMA 1989

narratives.title: 1989.1569_v01
narratives.narrative:
The prominent face on this bowl depicts a European, specifically a Portuguese man.  Depictions of Portuguese, the first Europeans to visit the Benin Kingdom in the late 1400's, are considered positive images on Benin royal objects.  The Portuguese, who at one time were allies with the Benin Kingdom, symbolize wealth and power.

Brass casters were influenced by imported bowls, boxes and other types of objects acquired through coastal trade with Europeans.  Although this bowl, which is missing its lid, was made by Benin brass casters, its shape is clearly derived from European bowls.  The application of gold to the surface is unusual in Benin art and the technology was probably learned from European visitors.

A pattern of interlacing lines is a popular design element in Benin art.  It can be seen on the rim, stem and base of this bowl and on other Benin objects.

title: altar ram's head (uhmwogho)
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: (Mamadou Koita, New York, New York); sold on 12 June 1976 to Harrison Eiteljorg [1903-1997] of Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 1989.

narratives.title: 1989.823_v01
narratives.narrative: Important male ancestors may be honored with wooden ram heads.  These heads are kept on altars where they provide a link between living family members and the deceased.  The ram is a common animal of sacrifice in Western Africa and is often associated with ancestors.

title: lid in the form of a leopard head
credit_line: Gift of the Alliance of the Indianapolis Museum of Art
provenance: (Merton Simpson Gallery, Inc., New York, New York); purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields, Indianapolis, Indiana in 1992.

narratives.title: 1992.61_v01
narratives.narrative: This lid in the form of a leopard head covered a brass container holding cola nuts, a mild stimulant, or personal items of a royal person. The leopard is closely connected to the power of the king.

title: face mask for Ekpo association
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: (Jerry Mulholland, Cincinnati, Ohio); sold on 16 March 1987 to Harrison Eiteljorg [1903-1997] of Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 1989.

narratives.title: 1989.831_v01
narratives.narrative: Ekpo masks embody beings from the spirit world and honor local heroes and gods.  This masking tradition supports local leaders and helps to maintain the independence of villages from the central authority and cultural influence of the king in Benin City.

title: pendant with horse and rider
credit_line: E. Hardey Adriance Fine Arts Acquisition Fund in memory of Marguerite Hardey Adriance
provenance: (The Grayson Gallery, Inc., Chicago, Illinois); purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields, Indianapolis, Indiana in 1996.

narratives.title: 1996.322_v01
narratives.narrative: This pendant with horse and rider was worn by important men associated with the royal court.  The horseman is a widespread symbol of male success in many areas of Western Africa.

title: head of queen mother
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: (W.D. Webster [1863-1913], England); Pitt-Rivers Museum, Farnham, Dorset, England; Charles Alfred Marius Ratton [1895-1986] Paris, France; (Papa Diop [1948-2012], Los Angeles, CA and Robert Jones, Indianapolis) (1) sold on December 14, 1977 to Harrison Eitlejorg [1903-1997] of Indianapolis; donated to the IMA 1989; (1) Robert Jones also sold under the name Robert Fitzgerald

narratives.title: 1989.821_v01
narratives.narrative:
Altars were maintained to commemorate past kings (Obas).  These altars supported a variety of ritual objects, such as human heads of cast brass, which were the focus of periodic rituals.  These rituals honored past royals.  The altar heads served as a spiritual link between royal ancestors and the Edo people of the Benin Kingdom.

All queen mother heads include a distinct one-shaped crown and collar.  In life, the crown and collar were composed primarily of high status imported red coral beads.  Over the eyes are scarifications, and between these are two marks indicating smears of sacrificial blood.

Objects of cast brass are made by the lost-wax technique.  A brass caster begins with a lump of beeswax, which is modeled into the object being made.  Details are impressed into the wax or applied with threads of additional wax.  After the wax model is finished, it is covered with clay and left to dry for several days.

The clay covering is then heated to remove the wax, hence the term 'lost-wax.' Molten brass is poured into the empty space once occupied by the wax.  The clay mold is plunged into water and broken open.  The brass casting is then removed and its surface is cleaned.

exhbitions.title: Selections from the Harrison Eiteljorg Collection of Arfican Art

title: face mask
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 1995.

narratives.title: 1995.125_v01
narratives.narrative: This mask was taken by the British during their 1897 military expedition to Benin City.  It was probably used in one of the village masquerades such as Ekpo.

title: bell
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: Collection of the Pitt-Rivers Museum Oxford, England before 1900...(Thomas Slater, Indianapolis) sold on July 7, 1981 to Harrison Eiteljorg [1903-1997] of Indianapolis; donated to the IMA 1989

title: female figure
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: (Thomas Slater, Indianapolis, Indiana) sold on 25 October 1984 to Harrison Eiteljorg [1903-1997] of Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 1989.

narratives.title: 1989.816_v01
narratives.narrative: This female figure depicts an attendant to the queen mother, that is, the mother of the king.  It was placed on an altar along with other royal objects.  This example is a rare instance of nudity in Benin art.

title: seated human figure
provenance: Butler University, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 1988.

title: palace plaque depicting warrior
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: Pitt-Rivers Museum Farnham, Dorset, England; Jeff C. Leff [1925-2000] Uniontown, PA; (Judith Ganeles, New York) sold on May 25, 1977 to Harrison Eiteljorg [1903-1997] of Indianapolis; donated to the IMA 1989

narratives.title: 1989.845_v01
narratives.narrative:
Plaques made by the 'lost wax' process were once displayed within the palace complex at Benin City.  The subject matter of the plaques includes formally posed kings, chiefs, court attendants, leopards and other animals.  Unfortunately, it is very difficult to link a particular individual or historic event with a given plaque.

This plaque depicts an important military leader.  The ceremonial sword in his left hand; anklets; bracelets; and collar assembly of coral beads, leopard teeth and brass bell indicate rank.  The barbed spear in his right hand and the sheathed sword at his waist are typical weapons.  He wears a garment from which beads or bells are suspended.  His hat has leather or cloth side pieces and a front panel possibly of metal.

The background surface of this plaque is adorned with leaf patterns and circular designs; the side panels are covered with a pattern of interlacing curved lines.  The holes reveal the placement of nails to attach this plaque to a palace wall.  As is typical of Benin court art, the surface of this object is completely covered.

title: altar of the hand
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 1995.

narratives.title: 1995.130_v01
narratives.narrative:
Within the Benin Kingdom, a man can establish an 'altar to his hand,' a representation of personal achievement.  The object is missing its separately carved base.  Unlike this example, royal 'altars of the hand' of the Benin Kingdom court were made of cast brass.  Royal altars probably served as models for the more common wooden types.

The upper projection once held a tusk or a horn.  The images refer to the importance of the altar's owner, the central figure with a sword of authority in his right hand.  Gunpowder flasks appear at his sides.  His left hand is supported by an attendant holding a spear.  Additional images found on this object are two other subordinates, two severed enemy heads and a horse.

title: female figure
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 1989.

title: human head
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: Dr. Robert Plant Armstrong [1919-1984], Dallas, Texas; (John Buxton, Shango Galleries, Dallas); purchased 24 June 1981 by Harrison Eiteljorg [1903-1997], Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1989.

narratives.title: 1989.819_v01
narratives.narrative: Representations of human heads made of baked clay are found on altars of Benin City brass casters and honor Igueghae, who in the 1300's is believed to have come from the sacred Yoruba city of Ife to introduce the art of brass casting to the Benin Kingdom.  In the past, such heads may have appeared on royal ancestor altars.

title: pendant with two entwined mudfish
credit_line: Anonymous Art Fund in memory of Louisa A. Vonnegut Peirce
provenance: (Tom Slater, Indianapolis, Indiana); purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 1998.

narratives.title: 1998.70_v01
narratives.narrative: This pendant of two entwined mudfish was worn by important men associated with the royal court.  Mudfish, a significant source of food, symbolize wealth.

title: ceremonial sword
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: (Sotheby's, London, England) on 30 March 1987 lot 69; Harrison Eiteljorg [1903-1997] of Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 1989.

narratives.title: 1989.839_v01
narratives.narrative: Swords with fan-shaped blades are an important part of Benin ceremonies.  They are carried before a chief in processions and used by him in a dance paying respect to the king.

title: staff with bird figure
provenance: (Pace Primitive Gallery, New York, New York); purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields, Indianapolis, Indiana  in 1992.

narratives.title: 1992.62_v01
narratives.narrative: Bird staffs serve as hand-held clappers during court rituals.  They are played by striking the bird's beak with a metal rod.  These staffs symbolize the power of the king over natural and supernatural forces, and recall a famous military victory of a Benin King.

title: face mask for Ekpo association
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Eiteljorg
provenance: (Lamine); sold on 15 September 1972 to Harrison Eiteljorg [1903-1997] of Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 1989.

narratives.title: 1989.828_v01
narratives.narrative: Ekpo masks embody beings from the spirit world and honor local heroes and gods.  This masking tradition supports local leaders and helps to maintain the independence of villages from the central authority and cultural influence of the king in Benin City.

title: chief's human face pendant
credit_line: Gift of Bonnie and David Ross in memory of Harry and Peggy Ross
provenance: Bonnie and David Ross, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 2001.

narratives.title: 2001.404_v01
narratives.narrative: Pendants with human faces such as this one served as badges of office and could only be worn by chiefs or other agents of kings.
